div.head: THE FUTURE OF THE "TIMES."
div.p: "Negotiations are in progress whereby it is contemplated that the "Times" newspaper shall be fornel into a limited company under the proposed chairmanship of Mr. Wa ter.. "The newspaper, as heretofore, will published at Printing House-square The business management will be reorganised by Mr. C. Arthur Pearson, the proposed managing director. "The editorial character of the paper will remain unchanged, and will be conducted, as in the past, on lines independent of party politics. The contemplated arrangements will in all probability require the sanction of the Court before they become definitive," . 80 ans quite sensational notice in the "Times" on Tuesday, Jan. 7. "How earth's strong pillars sbake! is the exclamation that barsts naturally from the lip as the astonishing rumour passed from one to another that "Pearson has bought the "Times!'" wrote Mr. W. T. Stead in the "Chronicle." "The story yesterday was a fable, but it had some snbstratum of truth But the circulation - the legend gave us all a sickening shoek. The "Times" has so long been a national institu ion that to hear about it being sold depresses mis as would the report that the Crown jewels had been pawned or that Windsor Castle had been let for a first class hotel." "The Times." "the bus, bloody and brutal Times' of O'Connell's savage invective, is still he Times, 'the asylum of the world,' as Kingako finely styled it half a century ago," pontinues Mr. Stead. "To maintain the "Times" in existence as the authentio and trustworthy chronicler of the Debates in Parliament, of the proceedings in the Law Courts, and of the progress of the world's history at home and abroad, is an object for which I for one would willingly vote an annual subsidy from the National Excequer. No other newspaper even aspires to fill its place. It is unique, solitary and indispensable. We can imagine England without its House of Lords, or even London without its Lord Major, but we cannot grasp the thought of England without the "Times." ! In 1901 Mr. Walter, who still controls the "Times," made this announcement: "The control of the "Times" has been in my hands for a good many years past, it is there now. And there it will remain until events over which mortals have no control shall place it in the bands of my successor No outside influence of any kind, of any origin will ever be permitted to affect the character of the great institution which was founded by my great grandfather 120 years ago, and which has never for a moment passed from the control of his lineal saccessors." The special interest of the proposed changes centres in the way in which they may affect the policy of the "Times." As Mr. Stead points out, two months ago the "Times" gave a plain bint "to the Tariff Reformers to bury what Disraeli called the dead and damned' corpse of Protection out of sight," and this may have "provoked the internal revolution that has led to the establishment of Mr. Pearson as controller of Printing House-square For Mr. Pearson was fir-t chairman of the Tariff Reform League, and it is assumed that whatever may be he political significatice of the late obscure shuffle, it is meant to rivet the bold of the Protretio ists upon the "Times." The advent of Mr. Pearson as managing director will be followed by a thorough reorganisation of the paper, and Mr. Pearson will play an important part in directing the for tones of the reorganised paper." says the Mail' "It is expected that Mr Moberly Bell, who has, as assista t manager, been no intimately associated with the recent activities of the "Times," will shortly retire. "We understand," adds the Mail, that Sir Alexander Henderson, late Liberal Union ist M.P., Wet Stafford, is associated with Mr. C. Arthur Pearson in the great changes which are about to take place in connection with the "Times" new-paper. Mr. Pearson writes to the "Westminster Gazette' to say that he is not acting for any party, whether of Tariff Reformers or other wise, "but it seems to be generally conceded. says that paper, that Mr. Pearson's con nection with the "Times" will make it more than ever a Tariff Reform journal." Mr. Cyril Arthur Pearson, the well-known managing director of the great magazine and weekly publishing business of C. Arthur Pear son, Limited, who has crowned a successful business career by securing the control of the "Times," is forty-one years of age, and was elueated at Winchester, according to the Mail." "Atter an apprenticeship on the staff of Sir George Newnes, he started "Pearson's Weekly," famous for its association with the Weekly, famous for its association with the 'missing word competition. He followed his remarkable success with this weekly by found ing "Home Notes," "Pearson's Magazine." The Novel Magazine'. "Dressmaking at Home" "Fashions for Children," "Home Cookery" "The Sunday Reader," "The Athletic Reader," "The Big Budget," and numerous other perio dicals "His career as an owner of daily newspapers hegan in 1900 when he started the "Daily Express," and soon afterwards founded the "North Mail” in Newcastle, and the "Gazetto and Express" in Birming' am. In 1903 be became vice-president of the Tariff Reform League and vice-chairman of the Tariff Com. mission, and in November 1904 obtained con. rol of the Standard" and "Evening Standard." In the spring of 1903 he bought the "St. James's Gazette, which he amalgamated with the "Evening Standard." He has pow secured control of the "Times," which has for genere tions been known as the leading journal.' Mr. Chamberlain has described Mr. Pearson as the greatest hustler I bave ever known." "Sir Alexander Henderson, who is associated with Mr. C. A Pearson in this matter, was born in 1850, and created a baronet in 1909. He is distinguished as the chairman of the Great Central Railway, one of the most progressive and energetio of railway companies, which be reorganised, and which, under his control, has advanced from success to snccess, until a few weeks ago it effected a very satistae. tory working agreement with the Great Northern Railway. He also carried through to sucoess the Manchester Ship Canal Sir Alex ander sat as a Unionist for West Stafford from 1898 to 1906. He is a member of the Tariff Commission and a strong Tariff Reformer. In 1903 be served on the Royal Commission on Civil Service Superannuation. He is largely interested in South American railways and in the coal and iron indnstries." The Times" first appeared in 1785 as the "Daily Universal Register." It assumed its present title in 1788. Its founder was an under writer at Lloyd's. For an attack on George III's son he was imprisoned for a year, and stood in the pillory for an hour and fined £50. In 1803 the second John Walter took pontrol; in 1844 the third John Walter, and in 1894 the fourth John Walter, the present controller. The "Times'" greatest editor was Delane, who edited the paper from 1841 to 1877. "Delane went every where and knew everyth ing and everyone," says the "Mail". "He secured such prestige for his journal that it was constantly used as a channel of communication with the public by the British and foreiga Governments. In 1877 he retired, and was succeeded by Professor Chenery, to whom, again, succeeded in 1884 the present editor, Mr. George Buokle, then only in his thirtieth year"

div.head: Bubonic Plague.
div.p: One admission to hospital is reported from Deirout, one at Tantah, and also one death at the latter place.

div.head: Grand Hotel Helouan.
div.p: A small dance will be held at the Grand Hotel, Helouan, next Friday, commencing at 9 p.m.

div.head: The Cholera
div.p: The Emir el Hag telegraphs to the Minister of the Interior that there were 8 deaths between the 6th and 14th inst. among the caravan following the Holy Carpet. Three deaths occured at Djeddah on the 17th inst. and 2 on the 18th.

div.head: Hospital Precautions
div.p: The Government has authorised the erection of temporary wooden hospitals in Cairo, as upon investigation by the Department of Public Health it was found that sufficient hospital accommodation would not be available in case of a sudden outbreak of epidemic in the town.

div.head: The Cedric's Arrival.
div.p: On the arrival of the White Star liner "Cedric", which is due at day break on Wednesday Morning with 110 first class passengers, and which will anchor in the outer harbour, the passengers will be landed at the petroleum quay by special sanction, the director general of the Customs' Administration. A special train will leave for Cairo after the disembarkment of the passengers

div.head: Plans of Cairo.
div.p: We have received from Messrs. Diemer (Finck and Baylaender) plans of Cairo drawn up in 4 sheets on the scale 1: 5,000 by Mr A. Hubert, expert at the Mixed Tribunal of Cairo. These plans which are the first of the kind to be published reflect immense credit on their author and also on the publishers; they should prove most useful. The plans are on sale at a collective price of P.T. 100 or P.T. 50 mounted.

div.head: E.T.C. Pocket Book
div.p: We have received from the Eastern Telegraph Company an handsomely bound and thoroughly useful pocket book with a calendar for the year 1908. In addition to much information the book contains a map of the world with tracings of the vast miles of cables which the Eastern Telegragh Company roles. London, we say, is the heart of the world, and it is equally correct to say that its arteries and veins are furnished by this company; indeed a glance at the map attached to the pocketbook impresses upon one very forcibly the fact that the E.T.C. is one of the greatest and most important factors in the universe.

div.head: Development of Mex
div.p: The " Anglo-Egyptian Mail" says that it learns from a reliable source that an influential group of English financiers is about to enter into negotiations with the Egyptian Government for the lease, for ninety-nine years, of a large tract of land at Mex. It is the intention of the company with which a highly placed Government official, who has recently resigned, will be connected to build a large number of dwelling houses on the land, the cost of which would bring them within the reach of that large portion of the population of Alexandria which is feeling the burden of the increased rentals.

div.head: An Egyptian Priestess.
div.p: There has just been placed on exhibition, in the mummy room at the British Museum, the mummy of a lady, one of the famous priesthood of Amen Ra, at Karnak. The mummy, which is undobtedly one of the finest, in the collection, is covered with a cartonnage casing, modelled in the form of the body; the face, being a portrait of the deceased, is thickly overlaid with gold, the eyes and eyebrows being inlaid with obsidian. The rest of the casing is occupied with representations of the deceased addressing prayers to Osiris Anubis and the genii of the dead, the whole being thickly coated with gold paint. The coffin is, like most of its class, made in the shape of a mummified body, the sides being richly decorated witb gilded representations of the gods. The face on the lid is, like that of the cartonnage, a portrait of the deceased. The date of this interesting addition to the museum is about B. C. 1,000.

div.head: A Complaint from Tantah.
div.p: A correspondent writes from Tantah to complain of the disgraceful state of the Garayariyeh Canal which runs through that town. A "Sadd" has been put in near the railway line to Mansourah, as a bridge is being built, and this has cut off the running water. All through the town the water is stagnant, quite black, and of a most unbealthy and objectionable odour, and yet none of those who receive comparatively high salaries to attend to such matters are apparently aware the facts-if they are, they are guilty of gross and unpardonable breach of duty. To add to the natural stagnancy of the water the natives make the canal a recipient for all housebold detritus, and to this disgraceful state of affairs, this negligence of public health, officials, high and low, the police, the tanzim, indeed everyone, close their eyes. It is really time that our officials of position realised that the day is past, when we shall overlook their negligence with the too oft heard "Malaish it's Egypt."

div.head: PARIS-GENEVA HOUSE.
div.p: Mm. Auberge is exhibiting her spring models at the Khedivial Hotel, Alexandria until the 25th inst.

div.head: DR. RUTHERFORD IN CAIRO. CONSTITUTIONAL REFORM LEAGUE. BANQUET AT SAVOY.
div.p: Dr. Rutherford M.P. was the principal guest at a banquet given by the Constitntional Reform League in his honour at the Savoy Hotel on Saturday night, when there were about eighty meinbers and gaests of the league present The arrangements had been made on a truly magnificent scale ; an excellent dinner was served ; the table centres were a mass of tastefully arranged flowers, and a hand station ed'in an adjoining room played a capital selection of music daring dinner.

Shiekh Aly Youssef was received with loud cheers, when, rising at the conclusion of dinner, he proposed the health of his Highness the Khedive, the toast being celebrated with musical honours and amid the acclamations of the assemblage. The toasts of Shiekh Aly Yonssef and of Dr. Rutherford having been daly honoured in turn, Shiekh Aly Youssef thanked Dr. Rutherford on behalf of the league for his presence among them, and for the sympathy which he had expressed for their ennse at the meeting of the previous day, and said that the active sympathy of both Dr. Rutherford and Mr. Robertson had been amply proved by their speeches in the English House of Commons. They could count upon these two men, he said, as being in favour of reform, and these reforms were most urgently needed. There was the question of educational reform, the questions of a university, public libraries, and numberless others no less pressing, and also the all important question of representative Government.

The Government had, be continued, promised to prepare the way to self-Government but in spite of all promises it bad continued in a policy which was little less than despotic, and which made Egypt a dependency of Great Britain Speaking of Lord Cromer, Shiekh Aly Youssef declared that the policy which he had followed of working the country with English heads and Egyptian hands had really resulted. in the breaking of the hands which served him He urged the enlarging of provincial powers. and said that a beginning should be made with the Legislative Council, which, with the General Assembly, was of immense importance to the conntry
The leaders remarks were punctuated with repeated bursts of cheering which was sustained for some moments upon his resuming his seat

Dr. Ratherford in replying expressed his heartful thanks and gratitude for the bonour done him in entertaining him at such a splendid banquet and for the far too flattering and generous terms in which they had spoken of his efforts in Parliament on bebalf of Egypt. He could assure then that he was constrained by a high sense of duty to visit their country and that his great desire was to study their problems, so that he might be able to render good service both to Egypt and to England and thus bring about the bappiest relations between the two conntries. His reception by H. H. the Khedive, by Ministers, Advisers, officials, and non officials, by men of all parties and by those who attached theinselves to no party bad been of the pleasantest and most cordial character, and he should always re. member with delight and joy their exceeding kindness. He was struck with the besnty | and the beneficence of the Nile with the fertility of their soil, with the glory of their climate, giving health and bappiness to millions with the relies of their ancient civilization, and most of all with the sober, industrious, and happy disposition of their people. The sun seemed to have entered into the inner most recesses of their hearts, bringing a joy and a peace that no man could rob them of, and that the world would not take away. or course he had seen a good deal to distress hiu as well. The presence of Europeans was not an unmixed blessing to Egypt. The attendant evils and vices were a menace to their simple life, to their moral welfare and to their evolution in the path of progress. He hoped that in imbibing what was best in European civilization, they would avoid what was base and degrading. Great and impottant reforms were urgently needed in education, sanitation, land tenure, liceusing, lunaey, the administra tion of justice and in local, municipal pro vincial, and national government. The dis cussion of these reforms the speaker reserved to the House of Commons.

It was an infinite pleasure to him to find the new spirit of civic and national patriotism steadily rising in their midst. Without this spirit all their financial progress was as sand in the desert, barren and without beauty. Man does not live by bread alone, and the people who are content with bational prosperity alone are of all pe ple the most miserable and the most to be pitied on the face of the earth. History was strewn with the wrecks of empires and nations, which had no bigher ideal:

With regard to their patriotic aims there. fore he was in heaty sympathy. He trusted all political parties alike would pursue constitu tional and reasoned methods in advancing their just cause. Angry and revolutionary tacties had a kuack of recoiling upon those who indulged in them, and wbat was still more unfortunate in retarding the wheels of progress. By subduing racial religious jealousy, by reforming social customs restrictive of liberty and justice, by affording equal opportunity to all, by personal and national sacrifice alone would they emancipate their country. England's mission in Egypt, as far as he could see, was twofold. First to enable Egyptians (and' by Egyptians be meant all who adopted Egyptian nationality) to steer their own ship, and secondI ly, when they were managing their own country, to protect them from all invaders. No more glorious service could be given by a strong nation to a weak nation rightly struggling to be free To this noble end he hoped his country. men both in Egypt and in England would beod their energies, and to this end he and those associated with him would devote their lifelong efforts

Dr. Rutherford's speech, which was translated sentence by sentence, met with repeated applause, and apparently fully satisfied the expectations of the audience. Beveral other speeches followed in the same strain, and M Khalil Zeine, Editor of "Al-Massawar" in replying to the toast "our guests" affirmed that the Egyptians would be assured of the support of the Syrians in this movement. The following telegram was received by Dr. Rutherford during the evening :
"Salutes from Egypt Egyptians, you defend their interests."
Young Egyptian.
Hafiz Awad was among the later speakers and the proceedings terminated at about 10.45 p.m.

div.head: THE NEW AFRICAN CO.
div.p: Sir Charles Bwan Smith presided at the or dinary general meeting of shareholders of the New African Co. Ltd. on Friday week, and in reviewing the company's holdings made some interesting remarks regarding their interests in Egypt and the Sudan.

Commencing with the Sudan the steamer business worked by the Sudan Development and Exploration Company has he said, made good progress during the year; the receipts from freights and passages for the year ending October 31st, 1907, having amounted to LB 23,148, as against LE 17,470 for the preceding year. In the New Egyptian Company we have, thanks to the excellent management of Mr. Beresford, who superintends the reclamation works which that company is conducting on the Nile, good reason to be satisfied with this department of the business. We bave, in these reclaimed lands alone, an asset of a value aquivalent to the bulk of the New Bgyptian Company's capital. The company, during the early part of the year, realised several of its properties and paid us a dividend of 10 per cent., but later the depression existing all over the world spread to Bgypt, where there bas been a great deal of over speculation, and the result has been that shares of all kinds have been thrown on the market, and those of the New Egyptian Company have also reached a market price far below their intrinsic value. We do not doubt that we have in this company not only a good asset but also a business in which we shall probably share from time to time when things improve again.

div.head: SAVOY HOTEL CAIRO.
div.p: The weekly small dance at the Savoy Hotel took place on Saturday night and was attended by a large crowd. Amongst those giving dinner parties in the restaurant we noticed Miss Cochrane with 16 guests, amongst whom were Colonel Herber, Mrs. Herbert, Mr. Royle, Mrs. Royle, Major Owen, Colonel Cuthbert, Mr. Gye, Mrs. Clifford Hall, Col. Harvey Pasha, Capt. and Mrs. Darell, Mr. Arthur Heywood, Miss Evelyn Heywood, Miss Hozier, Lady Oppenheimer. Lady Barttelot entertained, Capt. and Mrs. Dunbar, Capt. and Mrs. Schreiber. Count Kosciebrodzki had at his table Marquis de Fioravanti, Baron de Villenfanque, Baron Hein. Count Strassholdo, Mr. de Wagner, Baron and Baronesse de Menasce, Mr. and Mme Zoltan, etc. Messrs. F.A. and A.D. Gardner had a large dinner party including Mrs. and Miss Sibthorpe Barlow and Mr. Adda. Capt. and Mrs. Duffus, entertained Mr. and Miss Wealen, Br. Tribe, Mrs. and Miss Moneure Robinson. Capt. Kennedy sat down with Mrs. and Miss Pare Lyle, Capt. and Mrs FitzGerald with Major Haigh. Baron Felix de Menasce gave a dinner to 16 friends, among whom were de Martino Pasha, Mr.and Mme. Ferdinand de Martino, Mr. Leon et André Suares. Others diners included, Mr. Carter Wilson. Capt. Fuller, Major Pereira, Mme. Emily Sursock, Mme. Boustros, Capt. Evans, Dr. Bouboulis, Mrs. and Miss Carey, Princess Irene.

div.head: FAYOUM RACING CLUB
div.p: The Fayoum Racing Club, will hold its 3rd Winter Meeting on the 31st inst. There will be five important races, the prizes for which will vary from £20 to £55 There will be apeoial horse dancing and Bedouin Bergase by kind invitation from H. E. Mohamed Bey Mahmoud, the Mudir. It is hoped that a number of tour ists and Cairo notables will assist.
Programmes for the races many be obtained of Ahmed Bey Pathi, Hon. Sec., or from H. C. Simpson Esq, Hon. Treasurer.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner "Menepthah" sailed from Liverpool on Saturday last and is due here about the 1st prox. with passengers, mails and general cargo.
The Moss liner "Rameses" arrived at Liverpool on Saturday last, 18th inst.

div.head:
EGYPT'S FISCAL SYSTEM
LORD CROMER AT GLASGOW.
div.p: REPLY TO CRITICS

The Earl of Cromer in his speech at the dinner of the Glasgow Unionist Free Trade Club, on Friday week, replied to the criticisms which had been passed on his speech in London, more especially with regard to the Egyptian Customs duties, summary of his remarks appearing in our cable on the 11th. We are now able to give his statement in full on this point

There is" he said "one other criticism to which I should wish to allode briefly. It has been stated that although I may be a freetrader in England, I approved of a protec tionist policy in Egypt. This is a purely personal argument. Had I been ever so proteetionist in Egypt I do not see that the fact would help the tariff reformers much, although it might show that I was guilty of inconsistenoy. But, in fact, although I do not say that the present Rgyptian practices as regards both Customs and Excise duties are everything I could wish, the fiscal policy adopted of recent years in Egypt, so far from bearing the smallest resemblance to protection, bas on all essential points been based on free-trade prin cipiles. I will state the facts briefly. At the commencement of the British occupation an 8 per cent. "ad valorem" Customs duty was imposed on all goods coming into the country. Also, in all the towns, and even in many of the principal villages an octroi duty of 9 per cent. was levied on local produce. The latter pressed far more bardly on the population, and especially on the poorer classes, than the Customs duty. It has been completely abolished. Moreover, the 8 per cent Customs duty has been reduced to 4 per cent. on coal, timber, live stock, petroleum, and on some other articles. I wish, more over, to observe that whether the Customs duty in Egypt is levied at 8 or 4 per cent., or at any otber figure, it does not in any way offend against free trade principles It is im. posed for strictly revenue purpnses; and I am not aware that any free-trader objects to the imposition of Customs duties for such purposee, although he may regret the necessity for doing 80. What free traders object toistheimposition of Customs duties for protective purposes. (Hear, hear.) Now, the only important case which bas occurred in Egypt where this special issue was raised was in connexion with the duty on cotton goods. Until a few years ago, there were no cotton factories in Egypt. When they were established, an excise daty, equivalent to the Customs duty, was put on the indigenous manufactures Otherwise, local industry wonld have been protected. This Excise daty, which is similar to that which used to be levied on certain articles in the United Kingdom but a faw years ago, and which is now levied in India, was not imposed in order to please Manchester, as is sometimes alleged, but in order to prevent an artificial industry from springing up, and in order to safeguard the Customs revenue of Egypt.

div.head: PRESS ON THE SPEECH.
div.p: "TIMES."

We cannot belp regretting that Lord Cromer in his speech delivered to the Glasgow and West Scotland Unionist Free Trade Club yesterday showed no more disposition to promote conciliation between the two wings of the Unionist party than he showed in his address to those present at the Unionist Free Trade dinner on November 21. Generally, his speech last night was erambe repetita, as regards the fiscal reform controversy, and we do not think it needful to repeat what we said on the occasion of his last exposition of his faith. We prefer to dwell more on the subjects as to which agreement with Lord Cromer is easy than on those as to which it is difficult or even impossible.
"STANDARD."

Lord Cromer admits that the national revenue is inadequate for the national purposes, that direct taxation has reached its limit, and that Free Traders do not object to the imposition of Castoms doties for revente por poses. He thinks that by the exercise of strict economy something may be saved on the present expenditure, but he does not pretend that economy alone will be sufficient to enable up to pay our way, and be offers no other suggestion as to how we shall raise the money for reforms which he does not deny are urgent.
"TRIBUNE."

His whole speech was that of a complete Free Trader He repeated the weighty warning given at the Unionist Free Trade Club dinner in November, thșt Free Trade is the only sound basis of onr peaceful Imperial policy. He showed that his policy in Egypt was always striotly loyal to Free Trade, so that, when cotton faotories were established in that country, an Excise duty was pat on in order that they might not be artificially fostered by the Customs duty on foreign cotton. He took all the main 1 points of Free Trade doctrine as accepted without question by himself and his audience; he riddled, with all the certainty of an expert financier, Mr. Balfour's unsound doctrine of the merits of taxing "'s large variety of articles" : and he declared that Free Trade bad partionlarly benefited tbe poorest classes-from which it follows that they would suffer, most from Tariff Reform

div.head: WEDDING IN CAIRO. MOSSERI SUARES.
div.p: One of the biggest weddings of the last few seasons took place yesterday afternoon at the Jewish Synagogue when the marriage of Mr. Elie Mosseri, son of the late Nessim Mosseri Bey, to Mlle Laure Susres daughter of Mme and the late Felix Soares, was witnessed by an enormous crowd of their friends and rela tions. To synagogue had been magnificently decorated for the occasion, the crimson and gold chairs facing the congregation where sat the bridegroom, being surmonted by a bigh canopy of crimson and gold. The wedding was fixed for balf past three ; but long before that hour the guests began to arrive, the crowd being so great that the police bad to suspend all ordinary traffic in the adjoining streets. Rarely have we seen even in Cairo such a collection of magnificent toilettes and wealth of jewels as were noticed on this occasion or more bandsome women to do them justice. It was 8.45, when the chuch was foll to overflowing. that the bride arrived and was led through the crowd to her chair where sbe was met by the bridegroom. Variour of the near relatives were gathered round them, Mme Felix Suares, Mme Mosseri, and the three beautiful sisters of the bride Baronness Menasce, Mme Rollo, and Mme Suares. The bride indeed looked lovely in & satin gown of empire cut, draped tightly across the front of the waist and hanging from the back in broad wattean pleat. There was lovely lace draped across the shoulders of the soft corsage which was cut en caur at the base of the neck. She wore a wreath of orange blossems on her hair over which was the regulation tulle veil, and she also carried & small bouquet of bridal flowers. Her three sisters all wore bats of black velvet surmounted with handsome white plnmes Baropne Menasce and Mme Rollo had on lovely white dresses mossed with lace, that of Mme Suares was in grey heavily embroidered with a long peplum tunic of grey chiffon. The service was quite short and fully choral, the choir being accompanied by the organ and harp. The ceremonies over, the wine being drunk from the same cup while the veil was held over the heads of both bride and bridegroom and the ring placed in position, the organ thundered forth the wedding March, and after receiving the salutations from their near relatives, the happy paie made their way through the crowd and back to the palatial residence of Mme Felix Suares in Kash Doubara. Practioally everyone wbo attended the service was present at the subsequent reception, the rooms being so crowded that it was difficult at times to obtain ingress or egress The drive from gate to doorway was covered with rngs, baskets of gorgeous flowers flanking it on either side. Flowers decked the interior, an enormous corbeille from H H. the Khediva gracing the entrance hall and many others lining the rooms and passages upstairs where the presents were exhibited. In one salon Mr. and Mme Elie Mosseri stood to receive the congratalations of their friends : in another the most substantial buffet attracted a deal of attention while waiters were doing their best to cope with the situation and Mlle Alice so Icng connected with the family, was busy dispensing sweetmeats and bonbons to the assembled company. A continual stream of people were passing up and down the staircase to and from the rooms where the beautiful presents were on view. It is impossible here to give any complete list of the beautiful things that were laid out with great taste on the tables. There were some lovely things in chins, and bronze, electric lamps and objets d'art of all sorts and descriptions : big bowle of lovely design containing gold fisb-gilt coffee sets and all manner of beautiful things in silver - two complete sets of toilette necessaries at least, and some very fine pieces of furniture. Three beautiful fans adorned one table ; in a glass fronted armoire there was jewellery enongh to satisfy the heart of the most exigeante ; bracelets, necklaces and rings of all descriptions and values, ineluding one enormous emerald mounted as a brooch, a superb string of pearls, and a long chain stud ded at close intervals with fine diamonds.

As it is impossible to enumerate the presents, so also it is impossible to mention a tithe of the people who responded to the invitations with their presence. Amongst them we rotice Leds Valda Machell and Mr. Machell, Dr. Martino Pasha and Mme de Martino, Count Zogheb, Mme. Balai in a beautiful gown of soft apricot satin with delicate gold embroideries and touches of pale blue about the corsage. Mre. Rachael Cattani, one of the handsomest women present, was wearing a beautiful princesse frock of white cloth, heavily soutached, the wide revers across the shoulders meet ing at the waist over the collarless vèst of fine lace. She also wore a black bat with white plumes, and beautiful pearls about her neck. Her sister Mlle Frances was in white. Mrs. Schuyler Ross was very handsomely gowned in a transparent black lace dress relieved with velvet worn over white. Miss Ross was in a delighful cloth toilette, Dearly white, both long seni fitting coat and skirt heavily soutaob. ed; her most becoming bat was of pale pink satin, the wido brim lined with beliotrope, and the crown almost hidden by a mass of pink feathers. Mme Osorio who was present with her husband, the Spanish Minister, was in white with a pretty bat bear. ing shaded brown roses. Mme Gennerapoulo was in white with a bat of violet. Mme Levy was in a lovely frock of dull porple. Mme Ruth was in a dress of fine Irish lace bearing straps of oriental einbroidery. We noticed Mr. and Mrs. Svott Dalgliesh, Mme Heller, Mme Aghion, Maitre and Mrs. Carton de Wiart with their son and nephew, Senateur and Mme Adamoli and their daagters both in white, Mme and MITEN de Villebois, Mr. Saint Saëns, Mr.Grainger Stewart, Mr. Giulio Torlonia, Mr. P. Berra Nathan, the Misses Jaches, Harari Pasha and his two daughters, Nabar Pasbe, Mme Manson in green, the Countere della Sala, Countess Doncini, Counters Bracoeschi, Countess Siciliani and many other of the notabilities of Cairo and Alexandria. In her capacity as hostess Mme Felix Suares was very ably supported by her daughters and her song, Messieurs Leon and André Suares, who were indefatigable in the performance of their daties. The reception was in every way a most successful one and the bride and bridet groom carried away with them the hearties congratulations of every guest who was present.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: The Earl of Rothes and Mr. Crighton bave left the Grand Hotel, Khartoum, for a shooting trip on the Blae Nile.
The Earl of Kingston and Sir Robert Harvey have gone on a shooting trip on the White Nile.
H. E. Mnstapha Pasha Ibadi, Governor of Alexandria, will attend the dance to be held to-night by the Alexandria and Ramleh Ama teur Musical and Dramatic Society at the Savoy Palace Hotel
His Excellency Lou Tsing Tsiang has taken a suite of rooms at Al Hayat, Helouan, for the season.
The engagement is announced of Lord Arde, eldest son and heir of Lord Meath, to Lady Windham-Quin, only daughter of the Earl of Dunraven.

Mrs Abbott and Miss Cocksay, after a stay of two weeks at the Luxor Hotel, have left for Port Sudan on their dahabeah "Sayara." They will return to Cairo via Kbartoum and spend the rest of the season in the Capital.

The "Daily Mirror" announces that Mr Frederick Ryan, a prominent Dublin Sinn Fein journalist, bas left London for Cairo, to take up the editorship of a newspaper to be run on Sinn Fein lines for Egyptian Nationalists.

The following are among the latest arrivals at the Grand Hotel, Khartoum :- Mr J.J.. Neale, Messrs G. and El Karam, Mr. Lowe, Mr. L Graham, Mr. K. Rein, Mr. W. Vincent, Mr. and Mrs G. Desme, Count John Van der Burch, Count and Countess Hunyadi, Baroness de Langsdorff, Mr, and Mrs A. G. Cresswell, Earl of Kingston, Mr. H. Richardson, Mr. A. Staneley, Grafinven Landberg, Elias Bey Awad, Mobamed Bey Mustafa, Ahmed Effendi Kalaff, Sir Robert Harvey, Mr. and Mrs B. Parker Bidder, Dr. Lewinstein, Mr. J. M. D. Cardeza.

div.head: CAIRO POST OFFICE.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir-I note "a Sufferer's" complaint of yesterday and may say I went repeatedly to the P.O. to get letters, and often found thirty or more people at my section, D-L, and the froway mob of all sorts and conditions fairly frightened me away. Of course it must be a difficult problem with the mixed Cairo population, but it is rather a sad sight to see hundreds of people, many utterly poverty stricken and wretched, waiting their turn for letters, many containing remittances probably. I think since I was here first in 1909 the Cairo PO. has to cope with vastly increased business and has outgrown its capacity. The P.O. building is utterly unworthy of such a city as Cairo. The letters might be divided into a few more sections or each section could have an extra clerk and pigeon hole. I must, however, pay a tribute to the courtesy shown me by Mr. Williams, the Directer at Cairo, and his chief, Borton Bey in Cairo over some letters that were missing through no fault of the P.O. I regard the administration of the Egyptian Post Office as marvellously well run, considering the exceptional difficulties of the diverse languages and the continual arrival of mails by every steamer and the impossibility of obtaining the national staff that France, England, and Italy can obtain.
Yours etc.

div.head: GERMAN BANK IN PERSIA
div.p: DELAY IN OPENING
BERLIN, January 18

Hert Guttman, negotiator of the concession granted to the German Bank in Persis, interViewed regarding the delay in opening the Ben, said that the present time was unstable for entering on now and certain undertakings. The Germans must first strengthen their position in Turkey, Asia Minor, and Egypt There was no question, however, of abandoning the bank scheme. (Reuter)

div.head: THE MOROCCAN SITUATION.
div.p: UNREST AT FEZ
BERLIN, January 18

M. Picbon showed the Council of Ministers that Pribe and Spain were entirely in agreement regarding the policy in Morocco (Hans) Tangier, January 18 Unrest is increasing at Fer Pillages continua The proclamation of a Holy War at Mars kosh has been abortive. (Hans)

div.head: A UNIONIST VICTORY
div.p: Londos, January 18.

Mr. Bell, Unionist candidate has been elected for Mid Devon with 5,191 votes, defeating Mr. Buxton, Liberal candidate, who had 4,682 votes, and replacing Mr. Eve, Liberal candidate, who received Judgeship (Rater)
LONDON, January 19.

The Conservative papers regard the Mid Devon result as a triumph for tariff reform. Liberal roughs besieged the Conservative Cldb at Newton Abbot for 5 hours yesterday bigtit and smashed all the windows.(Reuter)

div.p: London, January 18,

Sir J. Lawson Walton, the Attorney General dead. (Renter) LONDON, January 19 It is understood that Sir W. 8. Robson become Attorney General and Mr. Rufus Isaac Solicitor General The Attorney-General died of double pueu (Reuter)

div.head: THE LUGH INCIDENT
div.p: Rone, January 19.

A dispatch from the Italian representative at Addis Abebas states that he had another interview with Menolik who reiterated that he urgently ordered the Abyssinians to withdraw from the Benadir hinterland and had taken measures to ensure the safety of the Italian Agent proceeding to Logh. (Reuter)

div.head: EXCAVATION OF THE HERCULANEUM
div.p: Roma, January 20.

A Commission is about to be appointed to prepare plans for the excavation of the Heron laneum. It will include Signor De Petr Professor of Archeology at the University of Naples, Signor Sogliano Director of the extensions at Pompeii, sud Bimor Onttini, Director of the Naples Museum. A Bill will be introduced into Parliament in accordance with their recommendations (Reader)

The Pope is better but is still in bed (Ruder)

The Hill Labour Conference yesterday evening unanimously passed a resolution that old age pensions should become payable without direct contribution at the age of 66 and also to the physically unfit. (Reuters)

div.head: IRISH POLICE ATTACKED.
div.p: DUBLIN, January 18.

500 men and women attacked twenty police courting a process server at Craggs (Galway). The party was severely handled and rolled in the mud and an inspector severely out on the face. The processes were torn up. (Reuter)

div.p: Tokio, January 18

Japan persists in her refusal to allow China to build a railway parallel with the South Manchurian line on the ground of violation of the Peking treaty. She threatens to arrest the work if it is begun. (Router)

div.head: TOURS IN THE HOLY LAND.
div.p: "Tent and Testament" (Williams and Nor gate) the author of which, Mr. Herbert Rix, died whilst his work was in the press is a very readable account of a tour undertaken in Holy Land six years ago. In the intervening time me changes have neurred, but otherwise the book contains a faithful description of the coon try and its people Mr. Rix explains that his object in visiting the Holy Land was to obtain such information as would enable him to "rooli " the life of Christ, and he was fouled with the, difficulty which confronte all tourists in that country, viz. that of finding two or more wires for most biblical series. This is a subject on which the best authorities have fallen Que and the task of endeavouring to locate the exact spots associated with the life of the Se viour was to light one, but the author went to a great deal of trouble in order to do this, sud his comparisons of the authorities" is of much interest. There are a large number of excellent photographs

Mr. Henry Prowde bus published new work of the "Itinerary of Benjamin of Tudela" containing critical text, translation and commentary by Mr. Marcus Nathan Adler In the twelfth century Rabbi Benjamin started from his home in Spain on an extensive tour, Visiting many places in Italy, Greece, Turkey, Sy. ris and Egypt, with what object is not known: Mr. Adler suggests that his intention may have been to endos vour to fod wylum for his brethren who had been severely persecuted in European countries, or be may have had trade! and mercantile operations in view, or the dealte to visit the land of his father. Probably the Tonson for the tour may be found in all these motives. The record of his Wanderings provides us with an interesting commentary on the condition on the various countries visited at that period, especially on the struggle better? the Crescent and the Orow Mr. Adler hosted in this work articles which he bribed to the Jewish Quarterly Review."

div.head: ABBAS THEATRE, CAIRO
div.p: Of a truth Signer Bracale commenced his rivalry early ! "Aida" in Italian at the new theatre in the same week as "Ana" in French at the older opera house; it was a bold chal leeworthy enough sustained and yet comparison is difficult; the music seemed for more naturally rooted to the Italian troupa, and yet on the whole the French company made the better effect. It was a construct as to the voices judgment is still tharder; for bow can one compare any bat the best possible mezzo-soprano from Italy with such a singer Madame Pierews, or the dramatic singing of the soprano with the altro artistico version given us by Madame Magne! But then these two singers are exceptional, they mando' the performance of "Lohengrin. The voices however, were distinctly goodSigna. Alloro mueb fuller, more finished voice thao those who usually hear at the Abbas theatre, and Signs. Gry is a really excellent mezzo soprano Signor Chalis has a fine baritone, "And he splendid rendering of the part Amennsto, Signor Sabellido - Ramses was impressive, but not always absolutely correct he was inclined to sacrifice accuracy to dramatic effect Signor Gamba, the tenor, should give some the performans W voice is excellent and powerful, but he is apt to over emphite Whitne may call the occasional Mon of the parts and to be harsh bryant there. The chords gosd, but apt to vary: on the ordboth it arty to pronounce bat the endhotor som hete botuto control over the hor r eth this at moments, and w as the continuity of the music, but be should be most effective in certain opere "Tes" for example. div.head: WARREN HASTINGS ANNIVERSARY
div.p: BALL AT KASR-EL-NIL

of the many successful functions which have taken place in the recreation room, Kaarel Nil Barrueks, the annual ball given by the King's Royal Rifle Corps last Friday evening to commemorate the eleventh anniversary of the wreck of the Royal Indian Marine 88. Warren Hastings and the remarkable deliverance of the Regiment, must rauk foremost, there was significance about the proceedings altogether beyond the ordinary The deft band of the decorator bad done its work artistically and well and the room looked very pretty decked with banting and evergreen set off with paper festone and orientallentenis. The ori ginal uniform of the Duke of York enclosed in a massive care and inscribed "To the Duke of York Rifle Corps by order of His most Gracious Majesty, George IV" surmounted by a photograph of General Sir Redver Beller and a silver bugle presented by Lady Roberts in memory of Lieutenant Roberts V. C. who was killed at Colenso in an attempt to save the gune-formed the frontispiece. In other parts of the room were relies of the wreck, including the steering wheel, life buoy and several engravings which were a source of interest to the guests

The arrangements were on largohen And in response to the three hundred invitations issued, some 280 guests put in an appearance, also the officers of the Regiment who entered with considerable spirit into the proceerlinge Dancing commenced punctually at 9 30 p.m., and it was early morning before the interval arrived during which an excellent and well served supper was served in a spacious marquee the capacity of which was sufficient to accom modate the whole party. At 2 20 m: the "Warren Hastings Quadrille" was announced, being the hour the ill fated steamer struck the rock, and preceded by the band, the dancers gathered on the square to the accompaniment of artificially terrified morning and wailing. Most of the guests stayed until 3 o'clock but it was an hour later when the National Anthem brought to selone & most entertaining and successful evening which must surely go down to posterity in the annals of the Battalion. It would be impossible to bestow too much praise to Sergeant and Mrs James for the excellence of their ontering and also to Sergeant James and Armonier Staff Sergeant Hunt on whom the many duties of decoration and arrangement devolved.

div.head: SPORTS AND PLAY
div.p: K.S.C Polo Tournament
PUBLIC SCHOOLS

The final match was played at Ghezireh Saturday, and was most interesting, the Harrow team playing a much better game than was expected. The old Wellingtonianson eventually by 4 goals to nil, but up to the end of the 2nd chukker they had not scored point, "The first chokker was fast and furious, neither side showing much combination. Mr. Bowen had several unsuccessful shots at goal In the second chukker Mr Maitland bada spill but luckily was not much damaged. The Wellingtonians had the best of the game and were always attacking, their shots at goal all going wide. The Harrovians played well together in the third ebukker the gume faster than ever. Harrow made a fine print on the ground and had very bad luck in not recording. Capt. Leigh and Mr Saunders being especially conspicuous. The Wellingtonians At last scored their first goal, and forced the pace after this and after several unsionosful attempts another point was added, the ball being dribbled through from a scrimmage In the fourth chukker Mr. Napier was in great form, hitting two goals--the second one, after taking the ball the entire length of the ground. The final score was Wellington 4 goals Harrom will. We congratulate Wellington on their well deserved win. The Harrovians made a Giant fight of it, and their combination was superior to that of their opponents

div.head: MRS. EDDY AND CHARITY.
div.p: - The announcement made in last week's issue of the Sentinel" that Mr. Eddy purposes founding " Christian Science institution for the special benefit of the poor and the general gnod of all mankind," has heen widely copied by the daily press, and as been the subject of favor able editorial comment. Much of this comment is along the line of that which appeared in The Boston Herald of Dec. 24, which was as follows:

The intimation from Mrs. Eddy that she intends to set apart one million dollars for a permanent fund with which to relieve poverty and extend aid to the nerdy, is a departure significant as a precedent, as well as commendable in itself. The Christian Science Reet has been severely received for its omission to carry on the life and charitable work under institutional aus I pices, Mrs Eddy, with her unchallenged power, can alter this, and by implication would seem to be willing to do so.
Alluding to this article in the Herald, Mrs Eddy says that about 1878 she opened a

Christian Science "Home" in Lynn, Mass, in which l'indigent students were given their board and instruction in Christian Science gratuitously, but the misconduct of some of these students caused her to close this "Home"

Mrs Eddy has consented that the institution which she proposes to found shall bear her name, therefore it will be known as "Mary Baker G. Eddy'sCharitable Fund." Its Board of Directors will be located in Boston, the recognised headquarters of her church. The shurobot Christ, Scientist, and in plan and scope this Pond will be an educational opportunity by by which indigent persons will be taught gratuitously the Science of the Christ healing as practised by Jesus and as made known to this age through "Science and Health with Key to the Scriptures, and the other writings of Mrs Eddy.

The sum of one million dollars will be devoted to this sole purpose. Mrs Eddy's benevolence will be open to all those indivi. duals who are genuinely interested in Chris tian Science for its truth's sake, and who shall present to the Board of Directors of the Fand satisfactory certification as to their indigence, their religious views, and their moral character. These certificates must bear the signature of some well-known Christian Scientist who can vouch for the facts stated therein. The students of Christian Science will be maintained by this Fund until such time as the Board of Directors shall have pronounced them good healers of the sick, and delivered to them certificates to this oleo The beneficiaries of this Fund, and the families of those who have families, are to be supported from the income of the Pond, and the number of students and their families to be supported will depend upon the Ancont of this income Among those to be taught and supported thus will be some petons who are trained and qualified nurses and genuinely interested in Christian Science

Mrs Eddy has turned this matter over to prospective Board of Directors, for them to work out the details of the charity, and necessarily it will be someonbilerabe time before the work of this Board can be completed. In the meantime no further information upon this subject can be given out, and no letters of inquiry should be addressed to Mrs. Eddy.
ARCHIBALD MCLELLAN
"Christian Science."

div.head: DELEGATION MUNICIPALE
div.p: La Délégation Municipale s'est réunie le 18 janvier 1908 a 4 h. 1/2 p m. sous la présidence de 8.E lo Dr. Schies Pachs
Prents: M.M, Yobis Pachs, L Escoffier, Maurour Bey, A. Ralli, Abani Bey, Dr. G. Valensin, G. Zervadachi, membros W. P. Cha taway, administrateur, L. Bedky Bey, seerd taire général. .
La Délégation et coupée des mesures del defense à prendre pour le cas d'une apparition d'une epidémie de cholera

Elle prend & wjet connaissance de notes de l'inspecteur sanitaire proposant certaines dispositions indépendamment de celles qui seront arretes dooord avec la direction géo rale des services sanitaires

Elle demander à cet effet a la Commission l'ouverture d'un crédit de LR 950 pour lo reuforcement du service des voiture d'ambu. lance et s'il en est besoin alle lui proposer de l'autoriser dans le cas d'urgence de prélever les sommes qui lui seraient nécessaires sur la nerva

Approuvant la manière de voir de l'espeo teur Sanitaire, la Delegation d cide de proposer la promulgation d'un arrété tendant la fer meture des puits qui seraient reconnus contaminés. s'occupant enfin de la question de la four niture de l'eau filtre . Ramleb, elle constate que cette fourniture n'a pas été gééraliace su polut que la Ville souhaitait et que justifiaient los mcrifices consentis pour la prolongation jusqu'k Ramleh de la canalisation principale d'ona filtre
Elle invite ce sujet l'Administration :

1. a prendre les mesures pour que confor mément à la convention de 1894. les bornes fontaines de faubourg de Ramleh soient ali. mentées par de l'eau filtree afin que la popula. tion pauvre puise avoir de l'eau filtrée à sa disposition.

P reobereber avec les représentante Auto risis de la Compagnie des Eaux les moyens de rendre plus facile l'introduction de l'eau filtre dans les maisons, oh l'ont rendu difficile jusqu'ici les fortes contributions demandes aux propriétaires pour la pose des canalisa tions dans les rues jusqu'aux diverses propriétés et en un mot d'appliquer pour les abounements de Ramleb les dispositions et les tarifs prévus dans l'accord de 1894 et les mesures sabatquentes prises d'accord avec la compagnie et si les dispositions de ces scoorde ne constituent pas des moyens suffisants, de chorober Ayes lo dita représentants par des concomions à de mander à la cotnpagnie, de généraliser le plus possible l'emploi de l'eau filtrée au moyen de facilitde exceptionnelles accorder aus 0000pants de locaux

Les concesions à faire par la compagnie se justiferaient par l'intérêt supérieur que présente la santé publique et constitueraient cer tainement un avantage pour alle meme par le fait d'accroissement d'abonnemental

Qrant la proposition de prendre un ar rete rocdant obligatoire la consommation de l'eau filtre dans les maisons de ce frebourg. La Délégation en ajourne l'examen jusqu'après s'atre rendu compte des nécessités et des résultats des mesures à prendre

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: Lundi 80 Janvier Après un début tree animé, notre marobe s'est almé en cours de séance pour finir cependant i on niveau plus élevé que ven dredi dernier Nombre de valeurs, qui étaient depuis longtemps négligées, reviennent en faveur grâce à la reprise générale. En un mot, bien qu'un certain nombre conserve des doutes sur la continuation du mouvement et persiste ne croire à sucun relèvement appréciable tant que la situation n'est pas changée, la plupart abondent dans le sens d'une reprise durable de non plus seulement à la pure speculation mais basée sur des principes solides, tels que la baisse du taux d'escompte et l'amélioration géadrale qui en est la conséquence. Quoi qu'il en soit, pour le moment la tendance wat baussière et si les transactions demeurent en somme restreintes, on peut dire que c'est la seule raison pour laquelle on ait lieu de se montrer réservé.

A remarquer, faisant contraste avec l'activité de ce jours derniers, on délaissement de l'A gricole et de la National Bank, qui cloturent sensiblement au même prix. Toutefois l'Agricole perd 1/89 à 7 23/32
Les Jouissanoes Eaux du Caire perdent aussi 4 frocs i 174 et les Nongovich Hotels 1/2 livre à 13.

En revanche, l'Obligation Crédit Foncier avaboe rapidement de 280 à 987 l'ancienne et de 253 256 la nouvelle, ainsi que les Lots Turcs de 166 a 170. LA Deferred Delta pro gresse également de 5 à 51/8, la Land Bank de 7 3/8 à 7 1/2, et la Banque d'Orient de 114 1/2 à 118.

Le Crédit Franco Bgyptien, plus ou moins délaissé depuis des mois, a passé pour ainsi dire au premier rang des titres favoris. Ce sont, parait-il, les arbitragistes avec Paris qui achè tent ici pour revendre sur cette place ou le prix est sensiblement supérieur, 107 francs, contro 104 ici. On a cloturé ce matin à 4 3/16 ache teurs contre 4 1/82 Vendredi passé.
Il y a eu un peu de demande en Investment qui gagne 1/89 3/8, en Hooker eten NewEgyptian; cette dernière se relève légèrement.

A signaler encore une avance de 1/16 en Dairs I 13 7/16, de 1 franc en Cassa di Boonto a 52, de 1 16 en Anglo American Nilek 314 de 1/89 en Estates 11/39 ot on Building Lande 1 1/4, et de penny et demi - Port Said Salt á 10,9; seule la Salt en Boda recale de 14,6 a 14/3 et l'Urbaine de 3 1/4 33/16.

La légère reprise constatée ces jours derniers en United provenait de l'arrangement inter veva entre cette société et le groupe de créanciers, arrangement aux termes daquel ceux-ci acceptent en paiement des obligations 15% Cette transaction, en permettant à l'United d'aller de l'avant, naturellement occasionné une détente et les actionnaire ne dtoespèrent plas de voir le titre revenir sinon son ancienne cotation, du moins un niveau plus avantageux que l'actuel.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel bomewards Great osre has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrivo in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in whi you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Rivers and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rote, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go on leaving Egypt is Sicily. Some will wait to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at ses, and we therefore subjoin a list shewing the time oo-cupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
The long sea routes -- from Port Said or AlexAndria to Plymouth, Southampton, London or Liverpool-occupy about 14 days. The short ones are as follows: Port Said or Alexandris to Brindisi 3 days
Alexandria to Messina .. .. ... 3
Port Said or Alexandria to Marseilles 5
Alexandris to Venice and Trieste... 3 1/2
Alexandris to Naples .. 3
Port Said to Genoa… 5
Port Said to Naples .. 4
Alexandria to Constantinople...4
Alexandria to Pineus...2
Port Said to Gibraltar .....7

The steamers of the P. & O., North German Lloyd, Orient, and Messageries Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, Bibby and Henderson Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt. As regards the train journeys from Cairo the shortest is that to Alexandria without change (3 hours). That to Port Said can now be made without change in 4 ½ hours. The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of stormers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg,

The quickest through Continental routes are by P. & 0. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste-Vienna express frem Alexandria As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packAges to any address in Europe. The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves Port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Perry boats having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calaia without changing. It has complete Arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio Rubattino Co's steamers which leave Alexandria weeWy for MESSINA, where one takes a train to TAORMINA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Glar ini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the towns much to interest the visitor The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Burns and bere also is a fine Cathedral The Greek, Roman, and Saracenie remains that are found all over the island, are an endless source of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history. having been & Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.c 212, when Archimedes was slain-bik tomb is to be seen The cathedral was once an ancient pagar temple PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants in the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city The Palasto Real is of a Saracenie origin and close to it the church of S. Giovanni degli Primiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Morenm. Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being bly 3 days NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Plorio Rubattino Co's steamers, whiob los ve dilyOne cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay--Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento (you can drive to) will take you on to Capri From Naples to ROM is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to peed comment bere Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a milway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be sprut admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe opened 35 years Ago, goes winding up through the hills & distance of four miles. The most delightful coursion outside Florence is that to Vallom bong, with its Monastery 3,800 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to S Filer, thonoe by dog wheel railway to Saitino. The ascent tight groves of oaks take an hour, and most striking pane ramas are unfolded to view. PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours; here there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one pisht should it possibly be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset. VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera tipar Pisa nad on the main line from Rome to Gongs. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (LA Superba) -- The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenAlly equal temperature - warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer. The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palace, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genos Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santa filled with its wonderful tombs From Genoa' to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour with a ball from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Domino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued)
div.p: The ITALIAN LAKES. VENICE is a 5 hours journey by mail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to PAN & quiet stay. The total abornice of vehicular traffic strikes one m very strango; no horse, cart, carriage or bietole is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the ses. No bills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the top of Campaniles appears above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon. Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one and a quarter hours by train by way of Monts: Bonta leaves Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremesso along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlessa on Lake Lagano in three quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lagano in two and three quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs." LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como, and reached by train in one and a half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charningly situated on the lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery, Around it M. San Salvatore, de Caprino and M. Reverso LOCARNO may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, sit ated at the top of Lake Maggiore, bas a mild climate, and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment" by Ciseri, and The Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion LUCERNE-A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne feel the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps In and around the town the walks are charmIng, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, eto, are very numerous. The Lake of Lucern abounds in delightful versions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus Burgenstock and Sonnenberg Beeding a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by stes mer, and the ever changing scenery on the trip from Lucan to Buelen in a source of delight to the lover of nature. BRUNNEN, chartingly situated on the most | beautiful part of the Lake of lucerne,commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the lake of Uri from Brunnen to Tuelen runs the famous Azentren THUN(on the Lake of Thun) half an hour from Berne and one hour from Interlaken. Quiet and quaint: sheltered from winds: just the place to rest and recuperate. Beautiful walks through woods, and along the lake shore. Kursaal, Con. certa, Casino, Races, Tennis, Boating, ete THE BERNESE OBERLAND. INTER LAKEN, & favourite summer resort, and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and' views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees, the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Girashach, Trummhach and Strach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed CHATEAU D'OEX, 3,500 ft above the ses on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry sir. Moch frequented by English people in Summer and Winter. ZURICH on the Gothard mute. Direct communication with Northern Europe Largest town in Switzerland, beautifully situated on the lake of Zurich. Theatres Big Concert Halle. Boating on the lake. Excellent schools The National Museum.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alex andria; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and Russian Steam Navigation Go. It is hardly necessary to point out to Tour ista the extraordinary interest of visit to Athens from an artistic, historical and archaeological point of view, and if possible tourists should average to be a Athens for the Or thodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival beld at Megans, for whieb & special train is run from Athens It is worthwhile to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be bad.

div.head: VENICE
div.p: LIDO (Venice) VENICE
From Venice or Lido, charming trip on the lagoon, 12 min. by steamboat. CLIMATIC STATION AND SEA BATHS, WITH CHINESITHERAPIC INSTITUTE. Express between the station and Lido for the Hotels.

The most important bathing station in Italy, Café-Restaurant and Terrace on the sea. Hydrotherapic Institute, Concerts daily. Frequented by the highest classes of society.
GRAND HOTEL DES BAINS.
Adjoining the sea. First-class hotel with dependencies & Chalets. 200 rooms & saloons. Electric light. Aqueduct. Every modern comfort. Delightful residence, without any mosquitos.
THE GRAND HOTEL, LIDO .

Hotel with its dependencies (Swiss Hotel) in the most delightful situation of the Lido at the landing place, five minutes walk from the bathing place. Wonderful view of the Lagune of Venice. Room from 3 lire, with board from 8.50 per day. No mosquitos. Very dry and safe air.
Address-SOCIETE BAGNI. LIDO, VENICE ITALY

div.head: TENDER
div.p: FOR SALE OF IVORY. Tenders will be received at the Stores Section Office, Khartoum, up to 12 Noon on Monday 20th January for the purchase of the following quantities of ivory which can be seen at Beit El-Amana, (Omdurman) any day from 9 a.m. to 1pm. (Fridays and Holidays excepted)
No. of Tusks. Rottles.
11 302 Aal No.1
4 71. Aal No.
13 169. Bar more than ten
[rottles
1. 6 1/2 Kling
1. 18 Khorda

The price quoted should be per Kantar for each quality shown. Tenders should be sent addressed to the Assistant Secretary, Stores Seotion, Khartoum, and be marked "Tender for purchase of "Ivory". On notification of acceptance of tender deposit of 10% of toll value should be paid by the tenderer. The ivory must be fully paid for within 3 Days of notification of acceptance of tender. In the event of failure to do this acceptance of tenders may be cancelled and deposit money will be forfeited. No ivory can be removed till the entire sum due is paid. The Assistant Secretary, Stores Section on behalf of the Sudan Government does not bind himself to accept any tender. 31766-8-8

div.head: Egyptian Delta Light Railways, Ltd.
div.p: The Egyptian Delta Light Railways wish to inform the public that in future servants and attendants of subscribers to season tickets will be admitted to the Station Platform at Helosan and Bab el Louk when in possession of their Railway tickets or on purchase of a platform ticket at the following rate One time ... 5 Mills 6 months 150 Mils Oue month.. 50 Three mouths 100. | 1 year 250 On no account will any servant or attendant be allowed on the platform unless in possession of one of the above tickets. The platform ticket will become absolutely forfeited as also the amount paid for same on misbehaviour of the holder or his neglect to comply with the directions of the Staff A. GARCIAS 31781-2-2 District Traffic Superintendent.

div.head: MUNICIPALITE D'ALEXNDRIE
div.p: La Municipalité met en adjudications construction d'une couverture en charpente aux Abattoirs da Mox Lo cautionnement est fixé L. Bg. 80 (quatre vingt.) Le cahier des charges est déposé au bureau Tecbuique o il peut être consulté par le intéressés tous les jours de 9h à midi, les jours fériés exceptés Les offres devront etre adressées son pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 4 Pevrier 1908. Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Delegation le même jour à 5 h. p.m. L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la men tion "Soumission pour construction d'une couverture en charpente aux Abattoirs du Mex. le cautionnement on le reçu d'une banque, d'après les conditions du cahier des charges devra être remis séparément au service de Is Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 4 février midi. Tonto offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écartée. Alexandrie, le 1 Janvier 1908. L'Administrateur 81739 39 (Sigué) W.P. CHATAWAY AVIS La Municipalité met en adjudiontion les travaux d'asphaltage d'une partie de la rue Porte Rosette. Lo cautionnement est fixé à LE 1800. Lo cahier des charges est dépoe au burea Technique o il peut être consulté par les intéressée tous les jours de 9 h. a mídi, les jours fériés exceptés Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté . Monsieur Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 24 Février 1908 Elles pourront également être déposos en séance de la Delegation le même jour 5 h. p.m. L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention: "Soumission pour Asphaltage rue Porte Rosette Lo cautionnement ou le reçu d'une banque, d'après les conditions du cahier des charges devra être remis séparément au Service de la Comptabilité Généralo avaat l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 24 Février 1908 al midi. Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sers foartée. Alexandria, le 11 Janvier 1908 L'Administrateur 31738-32 (Signd) W.P CHATAWAY,
